com.github.thorbenkuck.netcom2.annotations

Annotation Type ReceiveHandler


  • @Documented
 @Target(value=METHOD)
 @Retention(value=RUNTIME)
public @interface ReceiveHandler
    This annotation is used for a method that should handle am received Object.

    You register an Object as a ReceiveHandler in the following way: 

     
 TestReceiver testReceiver = ...
 CommunicationRegistration registration = ...
 registration.register(TestObject.class).to(testReceiver);

    This means, that you want the TestReceiver class to handle received TestObjects. For that, you will have to:

    • Provide a Method that handles the TestObject.
    • Optional: Also define the Session or the Connection as a parameter for this method.
    • Annotate this Method with @ReceiveHandler.

    This method:

    • Can have any visibility modifier you want (public/private/protected/package-private).
    • Can be called what ever you want.
    • Can not accept anything else than: A Connection, A Session and the Registered Object-type.
    • Does not have to have the Connection or the Session as an parameter.
    • Will not be marked as used by your IDE.

    For example, the TestReceiver might look like this: 

    
     class TestReceiver {
          @ReceiveHandler
         public void accept(Session session, TestObject testObject) {
             // Handle TestObject
         }
     }

    With this annotation, NetCom2 might be used in the way of an EventBus.

    Since:
    1.0
    Version:
    1.0
    See Also:
    ReceivePipeline.to(Object)

    • Optional Element Summary

      Optional Elements 
      Modifier and Type Optional Element and Description
      boolean active
      Overriding this Method allows you to disable an ReceiveHandler without removing the Annotation.

    • Element Detail

      • active

        public abstract boolean active
        Overriding this Method allows you to disable an ReceiveHandler without removing the Annotation.

        If this method returns false, the CommunicationRegistration will not use the annotated Method, therefore ignoring the annotation and the annotated Method.

        Further, if this Method returns false, it will not be saved and therefore not take up any resources to be saved, maintained and checked.

        Returns:
        boolean, whether or not the annotated class should be used to Handle Objects.
        Default:
        true
